utterances: Yes.
We asked a 37-year-old resident ZShad Ahmed what he thought about the discovery that Osama bin Laden lived just blocks from the sprawling military garrison.
Do you wonder in your own mind, how could Osama bin Laden be here when the military is all over here?
Do you wonder that in your own mind?
This is a very sensitive issue.
I don't want to talk.
This is relating to our military.
It's a question people are too afraid to answer here.
Nadeem Khan, who lives nearby, said he was startled to learn that Osama bin Laden had encamped in a costly compound around the corner.
(Foreign language spoken)
I never saw any movement around the house, but people say it was a mysterious building, Khan says.
They didn't meet anybody, he says.
Adding, when I asked people on the same streets, they said smuggler types lived there.
They would have no interaction with other people.
We didn't see them coming or going, Khan said.

The American operation that began with an ill-fated helicopter crash terrified the residents, including Amir Khan, who was awakened after midnight by the sounds of the low-flying American chopper, and subsequent explosions as the aircraft went down and was then destroyed.
(Foreign language spoken)
About 5,000 families have been waiting for today's ruling from a special court set up by the U.S.
Court of Federal Claims.
The special court was asked to rule on three test cases to help decide whether kids with autism should be included in the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program.
Today's ruling makes that unlikely.
In all three cases the court ruled against the families.
Rebecca Estepp has a son with autism.
She's also the national manager of a group called, Talk About Curing Autism.
Today is tough.
I've tried to stay optimistic all of these years.
We filed our case in 2002.
And I thought our best shot in the government was through the judicial branch.
And this is really a blow today.
Scientists who listened to testimony from the proceedings weren't surprised by the ruling.
Roy Richard Grinker is an anthropologist at the George Washington University in Washington D.C., who does research on autism.
He also has a teenage daughter with the disorder.
Grinker says that during the proceedings, the government called on many of the world's best known autism scientists.
The plaintiffs on the other hand…
Called chemists and a pediatrician with limited research experience - people who were not internationally recognized as people who'd a lot of experience either treating or researching autism.
The parents testify that their children became autistic only after being vaccinated.
But Grinker says the government's scientific witnesses found evidence to the contrary.

When you look at the home movies and you look at the clinical records, as the witnesses did for the government, you see repeatedly that there were major issues prior to the vaccines, either a child not making eye contact or not communicating, not being social, having repetitive behaviors and so on.
The families' case depended on two theories - the first was that measles virus in the MMR vaccine could trigger autism in some children.
It was an idea put forth in a paper by a British researcher named Andrew Wakefield in the late 1990's.
But during the vaccine court's investigations, most of Wakefield's co-authors retracted the paper.
Paul Offitt, a vaccine expert at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia says the retraction came after an embarrassing revelation.
They did it because they found that he had, in fact, been given $800,000 by a personal injury lawyer to basically launder these plaintiff's claims through a medical journal.
The plaintiff's other major theory was that a vaccine preservative called, thimerosal, which contains mercury, was causing autism.
But Offitt says that just before the vaccine court got going in 2002…
Thimerosal was removed from all vaccines given to young children and despite that there has, if anything, been, over the last eight years, an increase in autism.
The vaccine court is still set to rule on three more autism test cases.
But Stephen Sugarman, a law professor at Berkeley, doesn't expect a different result.
The claims under the vaccine compensation program, now, are pretty clearly doomed.
Sugarman says families can now try other courts, but the legal standards there will be even tougher than in the vaccine court.
Jon Hamilton, NPR News.
In yesterday's election, a new chapter of African-American history was written.
Hearing the president-elect speak, you could wonder if he was speaking of a party or of a people, of a legislative agenda or of a march toward racial equality.
The road ahead will be long.
Our climb will be steep.
We may not get there in one year or even in one term.
But America, I have never been more hopeful than I am tonight that we will get there.
I promise you, we, as a people, will get there.
The election of an African-American has a special resonance that can cross party lines.
Today, at the State Department, before spokesman Sean McCormack's briefing, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise appearance.
I'm getting ready to leave for the Middle East, but I did not want this morning to pass without taking note of the extraordinary election last night.
This was an exercise in American democracy of which Americans across the political spectrum are justifiably proud.

A few months ago, when Barack Obama clinched the Democratic nomination, we heard from historian Mary Frances Berry and from Bryan Monroe, the editorial director of Ebony and Jet Magazines, and we've invited them both back.
Welcome back.
Well, thank you.
Dr.
Berry, first, did you find yourself at all, either last night or in recent days, fighting disbelief, thinking that somehow, white voters didn't have it in them to elect a black chief executive?
No.
I thought it would happen.
Years ago, I wouldn't have thought it would happen, but for the last year, I thought that it could happen, and I've simply been waiting for it to happen.
And even when people talked about the Bradley Effect and the Wilder Effect and all these different effects, I thought, times have changed.
He's a different sort of person.
He's not an angry black man.
He's got every credential, and he has a skillful campaign operation, and it's, after the Bush presidency, who has those low approval ratings.
So, there's no reason in the world why he shouldn't win this thing, and I was simply waiting for him to win it.
Bryan Monroe, are you similarly unsurprised in the end?
I think I'm in - much of black America had both our fingers crossed, but more importantly, we were holding our breath.

I remember standing in Iowa the night he clinched the Iowa caucus and almost not wanting to believe that this, indeed, could happen, but knowing that somewhere, somehow, it could be taken away from us.
Now, knowing that we can excel.
Does it change things?
Mary Frances Berry, does it change things, or does it confirm changes that have already happened in American life?
Is that true, Dr. Pichichero?
When I woke up, I saw the chopper close up.
And it kept hovering closer toward the compound, Khan said.
The explosions from the crash shattered our windows.
I raced up to the roof and saw a huge fire, he said.
By late afternoon, the area had been sealed off by the Pakistan military.
The gray-colored compound was visible from a distance across a stand of poplar trees.
A red tarp had been put around the premises.
But there was no concealing an overwhelming feeling that Pakistanis expressed on television and on the streets of Abbottabad.
Resident Nadeem Khan said it is now time for the U.S.
to end what many Pakistanis view as the occupation of Afghanistan.
Mr. N.
KHAN: (Foreign language spoken)
The U.S.
should pull out because Osama bin Laden was their target, Khan said.
And they invaded Afghanistan to capture him.
Julie McCarthy, NPR News, Abbottabad.
President Obama had some choice words this morning for the press corps as he released his birth certificate.
NPR media correspondent David Folkenflik has that story.

Let's go back to what you just heard, how Mr. Obama started his remarks today.
Let me just comment first of all on the fact that I can't get the networks to break in on all kinds of other discussions.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I was just back there listening to Chuck.
That's MSNBC's Chuck Todd.
He was saying it's amazing that he's not going to be talking about national security.
I would not have the networks breaking in if I was talking about that, Chuck, and you know it.
